title: Tory conference 2014 - Osborne announces 2-year benefit freeze â as it happened | Politics | The Guardian
summary: conservative conference policy announcements - a round-up .
iain duncan smith says dwp to pilot ending cash benefits for some claimants .
osborne 's speech - a round-up of charity reaction .
redwood says businesses face retribution if they campaign for eu .
osborne 's speech - a round-up of business reaction .

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: george osborne , the chancellor , has used his speech to the conference to announce that working-age benefits would be frozen for two years by a future conservative government , delivering more than â£ 3bn in savings .
osborne has also announced plans for a google tax , a crackdown on tax avoidance by multinationals .
iain duncan smith , the work and pensions secretary , has announced that he will pilot a scheme that will stop paying cash benefits to certain troubled claimants .
they will get their benefits through pre-paid cards instead , so they can spend the money on food but not alcohol or drugs .
john redwood , the conservative backbencher , has said that firms that campaign against the eu will pay a price .

nicky morgan , the women 's minister , has criticised the sunday mirror for trying to get male mps to hand over sexually explicit of themselves using photographs of women taken from social media without their consent .
john whittingdale , the conservative chair of the commons culture committee , has also said the sunday mirror 's raises serious questions .
but sajid javid , the culture secretary , has refused to comment .
on the pm programme a few minutes ago he said it would be inappropriate for him to comment because he was responsible for this area .
it would be wholly wrong for me to give an opinion on this .
the reason we have independent regulators , we have independent courts , is that politicians do n't get involved in decisions of this type .
javid claimed the affair could lead to legal action .
he also refused to say whether he trusted the new press regulator , ipso , to deal with this , saying : it 's not my job to pass judgment on an independent regulator .
eddie mair , the presenter , seemed to find his reticence preposterous .
that 's all for me for the day .
thanks for the comments , including all the feedback about the beta version ( which for some reason seems to have been turned back on ) .
the guardian 's finest are mulling them over .
your complaints have certainly been heard .

documents.title: conservative conference policy announcements - a round-up
text: for the record , here are the conference-related conservative party policy announcements we 've had so far .
i 'll be updating this list every day .
1 - up to 100,000 new homes for first-time buyers under 40 .
2 - some 3m apprenticeships , funded by reducting the welfare cap and other welfare cuts .
there are more details here .
3 - stopping the european court of human rights over-ruling british courts .
chris grayling , the justice secretary , disclosed this in the telegraph on saturday , but details have not been announced .
4 - making mobile phone companies allow national roaming so that customers get a better signal .
sajid javid , the culture secretary , unveiled this in an interview in the daily mail on saturday .
5 - more tax-varying powers for wales .
6 - â£ 150m tax cut for people who benefit when pension post money is passed on .
7 - freezing working-age benefits for two years , saving â£ 3bn a year .
8 - a google tax , taking the form of a crackdown on transfer pricing tax avoidance schemes used by multinationals .
9 - piloting the ending of cash benefits for claimants in troubled circumstances , with benefits paid through pre-paid cards instead .

documents.title: iain duncan smith says dwp to pilot ending cash benefits for some claimants
text: iain duncan smith used his speech to announce that the department for work and pensions will pilot a scheme that involves paying benefits with pre-paid cards , not cash .

he explained why here : i have long believed that where parents have fallen into a damaging spiral drug or alcohol addiction , even problem debt , or more we need to find ways to safeguard them and more importantly , their families , their children , ensuring their basic needs are met .
that means benefits paid should go to support the wellbeing of their families , not to feed their destructive habits .

to that end , conference , today i can announce that i am testing prepaid cards , onto which we will make benefit payments , so that the money they receive is spent on the needs of the family finally helping break the cycle of poverty for families on the margins , change we can be proud of .
he told the bbc later that the claimants would have to use the cards in certain shops , and they would have to use them to pay for some items , but not others .
left unity , the new leftwing party , issued this response .
why do n't mps get their expenses on pre-paid cards ?
after all , it 's iain duncan smith himself who once claimed â£ 39 for a hotel breakfast .
mps treat us like irresponsible children , but they are the ones who are on the take .
this and the benefits freeze are just going to push people further into poverty , while the richest get even more tax cuts .
iain duncan smith rousseau/pa
the lib dems have issued a response to george osborne 's speech .
this is from a party source .

the liberal democrats have consistently blocked conservative attempts to freeze benefits for the working age poor , just as they have blocked our attempts to cut benefits for the wealthiest pensioners .
decisions on benefit uprating should be taken at fiscal events and in light of the fiscal circumstances .
it speaks volumes about the priorities of the conservative party that they see benefit cuts for the working age poor as a crowd-pleasing punch line for a conference speech .
lord ashcroft has published his latest weekly poll .
here are the figures .
labour : 32 % ( down 1 point from ashcroft last week ) conservatives : 32 % ( up 5 ) ukip : 17 % ( no change ) lib dems : 8 % ( down 1 )

at a fringe meeting david davis , the conservative backbencher , revealed that he was furious when theresa may gave her speech about the tories being seen as the nasty party when she was party chairman 12 years ago .
davis said he objected because conservative party members are generally so active supporting charity work .
the one thing said by one of my colleagues that made me crossest of all was the reference to the nasty party ' .
before big society we were the people who made society work , we were the principle props of civic society .
at a fringe meeting kenneth clarke , the former justice secretary and veteran pro-european , said the conservatives were taking the wrong stance towards ukip .
one thing we do n't do , we imitate ukip , we do n't actually explain why we think it 's rather a nasty organisation and it 's basic case is folly .
it is not true that we have lost control of immigration and it is all now run from brussels .
it 's not true that you can have a single market without the free movement of labour .
it 's not actually true that if people come to work here they do anything other but contribute to our economy .
it 's not true that the eu requires us to have the door open to people who just come here for benefits or just come here for healthcare .
and if we tighten up our own rules and we tighten up our own administration you can stop that , as other countries wish to do .
clarke also said euroscepticism had stopped the conservatives winning elections for the last 20 years .

i think what pro-europeans have got to try and do is have a sensible , normal , intelligent debate on the subject rather than the neurotic one which has rather dominated our party for the last 20 years and in my opinion is the principal reason why we 've failed to win an election for two decades .
the party i used to belong to did win elections , it was pro-european and it did n't get quite so obsessive about foreigners and so on .
iain duncan smith , the work and pensions secretary , is addressing the conference now .

he has just announced that the department for work and pensions will pilot paying benefits for certain troubled families with pre-paid cards , not cash , to stop families wasting money on drink or drugs .
i 'll post more details shortly .
in his speech to the conference this afternoon eric pickles , the communities secretary , strongly backed english votes for english laws .
after the referendum result , without holding back on more devolved powers for scotland , the case for fairness for england must be heard in parallel .
in the mother of parliaments , we ca n't have platinum card wielding scottish mps who can vote for measures in english constituencies , but not in their own scottish seats .
if i vote for changes to the nhs or schools or housing , i have to bear the consequences of my vote .
i have to look the electorate of essex in the eye and justify my actions .
not so the scottish mps , who have power without responsibility in england .
and as we all know - power without responsibility never ends well .
so the time has come for change the time has come for english votes on english laws .
great spot from whoever took this matt chorley ( @ mattchorley ) terrific cameron expression during osborne speech

documents.title: osborne 's speech - union reaction
text: and here is some union reaction to george osborne 's speech .
from frances o'grady , the tuc general secretary in today 's low-pay britain , in-work benefits are a lifeline for millions of families .
working families have already been hit by three-quarters of the total cuts the government has made to welfare and now the plan is to put them in the frontline again .
the chancellor 's new cuts would hurt working families with children most of all , pegging their tax credits and housing support behind rising prices and rents .
this is yet more chipping away at the social safety net working families pay into , putting them in greater danger of destitution if they become sick or lose their job .
it tells you everything you need to know that george osborne has unveiled more harsh cuts for working families on the same day as tax breaks for the pension pots of the richest one per cent .

from mark serwotka , general secretary of the pcs public sector union george osborne 's government , propped up by the lib dems , has slashed the living standards of public servants while the super rich have been rewarded with tax cuts .

days after voting for air strikes on iraq likely to cost billions of pounds , politicians of all parties continue to peddle the myth that there is not enough money around to pay civil servants , nurses or teachers .

documents.title: osborne 's speech - a round-up of charity reaction
text: here is some reaction to george osborne 's speech from charities and pressure groups .
on the benefits freeze from julia unwin , chief executive of the joseph rowntree foundation george osborne said today that the country can not afford such a high working age benefits bill .
he is right - poverty is a risk , waste and cost we can not afford .

but the plan to freeze welfare for two further years will make things worse for our economy , with more people living below the poverty line leading to lower tax revenues and the wasted potential of millions .

from matthew reed , chief executive of the children 's society the chancellor 's plan to freeze working-age benefits is a brutal blow to millions of families already hit hard by repeated cuts to critical support this cap would extend the period of the 1 % squeeze on families to half a decade - a ty family could lose as much as â£ 1,300 per year by 2018 as a result .

from alison garnham , chief executive of child poverty action group this is bad news for working parents struggling on low wages , already coping with rising living costs and previous benefit cuts for many of these families a higher income tax threshold will be of little help since what they gain in wages is largely clawed back from their tax credits .
independent projections by the ifs make clear that cuts in the uprating of benefits will be the single biggest driver of the sharp rise in child poverty expected in the next few years .
today 's announcement would inevitably put more children in poverty and further questions claims the government is on track to meet its 2020 child poverty targets .
from fiona weir , chief executive of gingerbread , the lone parents charity the latest child poverty figures have already shown a rise in poverty among working single parent families .
it seems unthinkable that the chancellor would take even more support from parents who are trying to pay the bills with wages that have scarcely risen in years .

from anne longfield , chief executive of the national charity 4children the chancellor 's speech will not bring reassurance to the millions of hard-working families who have carried the brunt of the recession but are still struggling with low wages and increasing bills .

on the google tax from diarmid o'sullivan , tax policy adviser at development charity actionaid the google tax ' proposed by chancellor george osborne today will be a potent weapon as long as it empowers the uk to override the type of corporate tax arrangements which are legal but abusive in reality .
the government has been prominent in calling for action on tax dodging in poor countries .
we now urge it to help those countries design similar rules , while beefing up the uk 's own anti-tax haven rules .
here 's the guardian 's video with a clip from george osborne 's speech .
here 's natalie bennett , the green party leader , on george osborne 's speech .
it is obvious our current economic model , as inexplicably praised by the chancellor today , has failed .
tackling the deficit by ruthlessly targeting the poor and vulnerable is not what constitutes an economic recovery .
we should acknowledge that we are a wealthy economy that can afford to pay decent benefits to everyone who needs them , as a decent , humane society should .
that must be paid for by rich individuals and multinational companies paying their way - something that this government has notably failed to enforce .
on the day george osborne announced his crackdown on the double irish tax avoidance scheme ( see 1.33pm ) , the irish government has been defending its tax arrangements with apple .
birmingham 's golden boys statue williams/flickr in his speech george osborne mentioned birmingham 's golden boys statue as an inspiration .
the press association has filed some background .

the larger-than-life gleaming figures of james watt , william murdoch and matthew boulton poring over their latest plans , stand near the birmingham conference centre where the tories are holding their annual gathering .

nicknamed the golden boys , the trio were among the most celebrated of the late 18th century - watt and murdoch at the forefront of steam engines and gas lighting development and boulton at the cutting edge of manufacturing .
osborne told activists : it 's an image that captures a golden age for our country , when the spirit of invention was alive and the marriage of business and science made everything possible .
a time when we faced the future with confidence , and were n't afraid of the big answers to the big questions .
i want us to be that britain .
let 's raise the ambition of the nation so that everyone has the chance to succeed .

the recently-restored 1956 bronze by william bloye , a former head of sculpture at birmingham school of art , is finished with gold and set on a portland stone plinth in the city 's broad street and was originally planned to stand outside a never-built planetarium .

one local reveals online that it is thought by some viewers to resemble a scene less likely to be invoked by osborne as he warns of continued austerity : three men discuss the size of a recent gas bill .
alistair burt , the former foreign office minister , says john redwood 's comment is so extreme he thinks redwood ca n't really have said it .
alistair burt ( @ alistairburtmp ) finally the j redwood mask slips away with his threat to business which disagrees with him .
i thought we were democrats ?
surely misquoted ?

documents.title: redwood says businesses face retribution if they campaign for eu
text: during the scottish referendum campaign david cameron strongly criticised the snp government for trying to silence businesses that wanted to speak out against independence .

so it will be interesting to hear what he has to say about john redwood who , aping jim sillars , has warned that businesses could face retribution at the hands of campaigners and consumers if they speak out in favour of eu membership .

according to the telegraph , redwood told a fringe meeting that business leaders would face a very dear economic and financial price if they tried to throw the weight of their firms behind the pro-eu cause .

if [ business leaders ] do n't understand that now they will find those of us organising the get out ' campaign will then make life difficult for them by making sure that their customers , their employees and their shareholders who disagree with them - and there will be a lot who disagree with them - will be expressing their views very forcefully and will be destablising their corporate governance .
this is absolutely crucial that these people get this .

that it will be deeply disruptive to their businesses , and maybe even to their own tenure of their jobs , if a chief executive with a handful of shares thinks he can put the voice of a multi-national corporation behind a highly intense political argument in one country in which they operate .
it would be extremely foolish and we must make sure they have to pay a very dear economic and financial price were they to try that ill-judged thing .
if any labour figure said anything like this , david cameron would denounce them in a trice .
i 'll find out what number 10 is saying about this .

documents.title: osborne 's speech - a round-up of business reaction
text: here is some business reaction to george osborne 's speech .

from john cridland , the cbi director general the economic recovery is strengthening , but it 's certainly not job done , so businesses will be buoyed to hear the chancellor commit to an economic plan for the long-term .
investment in infrastructure , like runways , and in skills are the right choices to boost growth across the country .

from simon walker , director general of the institute of directors at the heart of the chancellor 's speech was a welcome recognition of the centrality of business and enterprise to every other area of government activity the iod has long maintained that if you believe in free markets , you have to recognise when the system breaks down or trust in it is eroded .

tackling the perception that multinationals get a sweeter deal than the vast majority of businesses is the right thing to do , but can only be effective when combined with a radical simplification of the uk 's sprawling tax code .

from john longworth , director general of the british chambers of commerce the chancellor made a blistering affirmation about the importance of the uk 's economic progress - brushing aside nimbyism and those who do n't believe growth is essential for britain 's future however there were two pieces missing .
we would have liked the chancellor 's speech to address access to finance , as this is so important to raising business investment and long-term sustainable growth .
also a commitment to export support should be a government priority , as it is vital to re-balancing the economy .
from terry scuoler , ceo of the eef employer 's organisation there was no mention of eu membership , but [ osborne ] did talk about the importance of attracting businesses and investment .
the two go hand in hand .
he also signalled that spending cuts will continue to do the heavy-lifting on deficit reduction .

this is good news , but he must ensure that the government implements these in such a way that we continue to maintain momentum on new technology , innovation and infrastructure as these will shore up the uk 's competitiveness .
here 's the full statement from chris leslie , the shadow chief secretary to the treasury , responding to george osborne 's speech on behalf of labour .
he does not explicitly reject the benefit freeze , but he implies labour would not implement it , saying the party would balance the books in a fairer way .
having failed to balance the books in this parliament george osborne has made his choice .
he is choosing to give the richest one per cent a â£ 3 billion-a-year tax cut and opposing a mansion tax while cutting tax credits which make work pay for millions of striving families .
while working people have seen their wages fall by â£ 1600 a year since 2010 , the tories have once again shown they are the party of a privileged few at the top .
labour will balance the books as soon as possible in the next parliament , but we will do so in a fairer way .
we will reverse the tory tax cut for millionaires , stop paying the winter fuel allowance to the richest five per cent of pensioners and cap child benefit rises at one per cent for two years .
iain dale , the political publisher and blogger , says he 's been told that another ukip defection is on the way .
iain dale ( @ iaindale ) told by a normally reliable source another tory ukip defection is imminent .
stand by your beds .

documents.title: labour party reaction to osborne 's speech
text: here is some labour reaction to george osborne 's speech .

from stewart wood , the shadow cabinet office minister and one of ed miliband 's key policy advisers stewart wood ( @ stewartwood ) osborne 's moved from trickle-down to trickle-up economics : the view that the govt 's role is to step in to make inequality grow more & more .
from andy burnham , the shadow health secretary andy burnham ( @ andyburnhammp ) telling line from @ twitterid osborne speech : `` do n't let anyone in this party concede the nhs to labour '' .
suggests he thinks they already have .
from chris leslie , the shadow chief secretary to the treasury chris leslie ( @ chrislesliemp ) should we be surprised ?

george osborne chooses to give richest 1 % a â£ 3bn tax cut while hitting tax credits which make work pay # forthefew from willie bain , a shadow scotland office mininster william bain ( @ william bain ) osborne 's made his choice : more pain/inequality for ordinary working people .
no wonder polls say britain 's on course to choose change in may nic wistreich is not a labour mp , but i 'll include this here because it 's an interesting comment on the speech from the left .
nic wistreich ( @ netribution ) so osborne did n't read piketty this summer then ?
making it cheaper to inherit large wealth , but much harder to be poor .
extinction economics
here is some twitter comment on the speech from journalists .

from the spectator 's fraser nelson fraser nelson ( @ frasernelson ) borrowing callaghan is one thing but i do believe osborne lifted the end of his speech ( the `` choose '' bit ) from @ twitterid 's trainspotting the full trainspotting quote is here .
from the house magazine 's sam macrory sam macrory ( @ sammacrory ) sad that osborne 's trainspotting 'choose life ' ending ran out of steam before the 'choose a fking big television ' bit .

# cpc14 from sky 's faisal islam faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) been following george osborne for 6 years not a lot new in that , but definitely one of his best speeches that i 've heard from the times 's tim montgomerie tim montgomerie ( @ timmontgomerie ) am told osborne 's `` google tax '' is answer to my point about fair austerity ( - would like to see details of it .
from the times 's david aaronovitch david aaronovitch ( @ daaronovitch ) osborne speech explained : pensioners vote & we all love them .
the working poor and the unemployed often do n't vote , and we love them less .
from the guardian 's owen jones owen jones ( @ owenjones84 ) most britons in poverty are in work , and george osborne has committed to cut their in-work benefits .
`` for hard working people '' indeed # cpc14
george osborne 's welfare freeze would only raise a quarter of the amount that the tories want to raise from welfare cuts , the ft 's jim pickard points out .
jim pickard ( @ pickardje ) camp osborne admits that the tories would cut â£ 12bn of benefits next parliament - the â£ 3bn freeze would only tackle a quarter of this .

documents.title: osborne 's `` google tax '' - details
text: obviously no one in government would ever dream of naming a company being targeted by george osborne 's new clampdown on tax avoidance .
but a senior source has been telling journalists in birmingham that they might like to know that some people are referring to it as the google tax .
here are some more details .
osborne hopes raise hundreds of millions of pounds from the google tax .
it will be part of a tax avoidance package being announced in the autumn statement that will raise billions .
the new measure will specifically target the double irish - a transfer pricing scheme used by companies like google .
this involves transferring profits internally , first to ireland ( which does not have us transfer pricing rules ) , and then to another low-tax jurisdiction , to limit a firm 's tax liability .
according to the wikipedia double irish page ( which our source is encouraging us to read ) , other companies using this include facebook , apple , microsoft , yahoo and starbucks .
companies using this strategy will be made to pay tax on profits as if they were incurred in the uk , and not in the foreign jurisdiction chosen through the tax avoidance scheme .
the move complements a similar attempt to crack down on multinational tax avoidance through the g20 's base erosion and profit shifting ( beps ) initiative .

documents.title: osborne 's benefit freeze - details
text: here are more details of the benefits freeze .
they are from the tories .
working-age benefits will be frozen for two years from april 2016 .
this follows a 1 % cap on increases that was announced in 2012 .
working-age benefits currently covered by the 1 % cap will be covered , and housing benefit will also be covered .

the full list includes : jobseeker 's allowance , tax credits , universal credit , child benefit , income support , the work-related activity component of employment and support allowance and the local housing allowance rates in housing benefit .
some minor benefits , like maternity pay , paternity pay , sickness pay and adoption pay wo n't be covered .
the freeze will raise around â£ 1.6bn in 2016/17 , rising to around â£ 3.2bn a year in 2017/18 .
disability benefits and pensioners benefits will not be included .
the tories justify the move by saying that since 2007 earnings have rise by 14 % , while working-age benefits have risen by 22.4 % .
by 2017 , after the two-year freeze , earnings and benefits will have risen by the same amount .

documents.title: osborne 's speech - snap verdict
text: osborne 's speech - snap verdict : not exactly conservative , was it .
george osborne has always been an enthusiast for change and technology .

i was once told by one of his colleagues that that key difference between osborne and david cameron was that , faced with a proposal to put a big superstore on the edge of town , cameron would be instinctively against , while osborne would be instinctively in favour .
today he unleashed his inner builder/engineer as never before .
it was interesting and challenging , as was his passage about the north/south divide .
but this was a speech where there story trumps the rhetoric .
osborne announced what would be another huge welfare cut for working age people .
this would save â£ 3bn , he said , in addition to another â£ 13bn he plans to save from ongoing whitehall spending cuts .
yet , in total , the next government would need to cut annual spending by â£ 25bn , he claimed .
that leaves only another â£ 9bn to go .
osborne says britain is a lantern in a storm .
he ends with a list of things that britain should choose , culminating in choose the future and choose david cameron .
and that 's it .
the speech is over , and osborne has been getting a standing ovation .
osborne says he is abolishing the tax levied when pension pots are passed on .
the tax cut comes into effect today , he says .
osborne says he has one final choice to address .
he turns to pensions , and the pension tax cut announced overnight .
osborne says he grew up in london .
he is full of wonder for the way it has become a global capital .
but he is the first chancellor in almost 40 years to represent a seat in the north of england .
he can see the risk a powerful london creates .
the answer is not to knock down london .
it is to build up a northern powerhouse .
it wo n't be done quickly .
but that is not a reason for not trying .
follow michael heseltine 's example , he says .
elected mayors should be part of this , he says .
reducing the gap between north and south should be one of the central ambitions of the next conservative government , he says .
osborne says britain has spent 40 years avoiding a decision about a new runway in the south east of england .
we need to take a decision about the future now , he says .
what would those golden boys in the statue of the steam engine inventors agreed that ?
would they have blocked shale gas exploration ?
and would they have opposed power stations ?
or the building of new houses ?
or gm food ?
no , he says .
they would have chosen the future .
and britain must choose the future too .
osborne says he says to technology companies they are welcome in britain with open arms .
they have advantages here , like an nhs to keep staff healthy .
he says britain has low taxes .
but the government expects those taxes to be paid .
some technology companies go to extraordinary lengths to avoid those taxes .
the government will put a stop to it , he says .
osborne says government will stop international technology companies avoiding tax in the uk .
osborne says it is not by accident that more than 2m private sector jobs have been created .
it has been government policy to support these jobs .
but labour are anti-jobs , he says .
he says he promised that britain would have the lowest business taxes of any large country in the world , and he is on track to achieve this .
labour would reverse this , he says .
when we choose to be on the side of enterprise , we are on the side of the british people , he says .
it is the conservative party that understands markets must be fair if they are to be free .
osborne says the party of progress is going to make another choice .
let 's abolish long-term youth unemployment together , he says .
reminding activists of the plans announced on sunday , he says the tories would lower the welfare cap , and use the money to fund 3m more apprenticeships .
osborne says he is increasing the tax-free personal allowance .
this means working people are keeping up to â£ 800 more of their own money .

documents.title: osborne says his benefit freeze would save â£ 3bn
text: osborne says this would save more than â£ 3bn .

documents.title: osborne announces working-age benefits to be frozen for two years after 2015
text: osborne says for two years spending will be cut at the same rate as during this parliament .
that will save â£ 13bn .
and there will have to be less welfare spending too .
the elderly and the disabled will be protected .
but we can not carry on spending â£ 100bn on people of working age .
benefits have risen more than earnings since the recession , he says .
that is not sustainable or not fair .
working age benefits will be frozen for two years , osborne says .
osborne says the record of this government has settled the argument for good ; labour were wrong , and the tories were right .
the home office budget has fallen , but crime is down .
education bureaucracy has been cut by half .
but standards are going up , he says .
osborne says politicians face a choice : telling people that this can be done without hard choices , or levelling with people .
he says it is only because he levelled with people that he took them with him .
the latest treasury estimate is that there is a need for â£ 25bn permanent public spending cuts , or tax rises .
and , osborne says , he tells the hall in all candour that the option of raising taxes to tackle a deficit no longer existed .
( he 's half-quoting james callaghan 's speech disowning keynesianism in the 1970s . )
osborne says that when scotland gets more power over taxes , they will use that to cut taxes , not raise them .
and wales and northern ireland should have more power over tax too , he says .
osborne says economic security is at the heart of what the tories offer .
so high street banks will be ringfences , and the bank of england is getting extra powers to tackle a potential house price boom .
the tories will eliminate the deficit , and then run surpluses in the good years .
that means raising more money than the government spends .
labour say they would do the same .
but under their plan they would spend â£ 28bn a year more , experts say .
osborne says there are some immediate choices to face .
a previous speaker spoke about the impact of a financial crisis .
he was working in a northern rock branch .
we must never go back to that .
the country faces choices , he says .
the past or the future - that is the choice britain faces .
and we in this hall have no doubt - we will choose the future .
osborne says the tories are the only party with a plan to fix the economy .
that is the leadership the conservatives have offered , he says .
and he praises david cameron 's leadership .
osborne says labour 's promises are built on sand .
do n't concede the nhs to labour .
the government has only been able to increase its budget because it took tough decisions .
the real party of the nhs is in this hall .
osborne says there is a fashionable claim that the link between personal prosperity and the state of the economy has been broken .
that is a dangerous myth , he says .
( for more on this , and my take on it , see 9.34am . )
osborne says this is what the tories have always done .
labour can not do that .
look at their conference .
ed miliband made a pitch for office that was so forgettable that he forgot it himself .
but not talking about the deficit was not just a hapless mistake .
it was a disqualification for the high office he seeks .
we are living through an economic upheaval as big as the industrial revolution , he says .
the conservatives applaud the power this puts in the hands of citizens .
it can be exciting , but unsettling too .
a single app can disrupt an entire industry .
these are big questions that require big answers .
the next conservative government will provide them .
there are huge risks , he says .
there is still a big deficit , and the national debt is dangerously high .
anyone who thinks we should ease up should look at continental countries .
they eased up , and they are in trouble .
and there are dangers around the world .
he invites the audience to salute the courage of the armed forces .
osborne says real people are behind these statistics .
people have jobs .
but he does not stand here marvelling at what has been done .
he is humbled by what needs to be done next .
we will finish the job that we have started .
osborne says britain itself up after the recession .
and two years ago , when critics said they should abandon their plan , the tories stuck to their plan .
it is now the fastest-growing , deficit-reducing country on earth , he says .
britain decided to leave behind a path of borrowing .
it chose the future .
long-term unemployment is down , youth unemployment is down , unemployment is falling quickly , the long-term economic plan is working , he says .

documents.title: osborne says uk can be most prosperous county on earth
text: osborne says the tories are the party of progress , the party of enterprise , of the wide open seas and global free trade .
they are laying out their case to the nation , and asking it to choose the future , not the past .
he mentions the birmingham statue of the golden boys who invented the steam engine .
they had aspirations .
he wants us to be that nation , so everyone has a chance to succeed .
i believe it is perfectly possible for britain to be the most prosperous country on earth .

documents.title: george osborne 's speech
text: george osborne is about to start .
digby jones introduces george osborne as the nation 's finance director .
people said osborne was on the wrong track , he says .
but osborne did what he thought was right , he says .
digby jones says he wants to hear politicians from all parties say there is nothing wrong with making and keeping a profit .
business figures should not be the whipping boy of an ideology , he says .
we all want the low-paid to get more money , he says .
but it has to be earned .
otherwise inflation goes up .
he says he wants an end to the situation where half of school leavers do not get grade c or above in maths and english .
you do not set the poor free by giving them money , he says .
you set them free by giving them an education .
alex hunt ( @ ialexhunt ) trade minister in last labour government , digby jones , is introducing the chancellor at # cpc14 and jones uses this line about those who wo n't work .
tim shipman ( @ shippersunbound ) digby jones on people who wo n't work : `` i 'd stick an exocet up their chuff '' .
pearls spin around the necks of the blue rinse brigade
digby jones says it will be a farce if scottish mps are allowed to carry on voting on taxation affecting birmingham when english mps no longer decide taxation in scotland .
he also says that he is not here to represent any party .
as a minister , he was not a labour member , he says .
he claims that he is the only person to have served as a goverment minister without being a member of the governing party .
his only constituency is business , he says .
digby jones , the former cbi director general and a trade minister in the labour government , is on the stage now .
he is introducing george osborne .
in his speech to the conference patrick mcloughlin , the transport secretary , said he wanted 2018 to be year of the engineer .
we should recognise what brilliant engineers we have in this country .
i am immensely proud of what they achieve .
and so in 2018 - when crossrail is complete - i want us to do something special .
a year of the engineer - to excite a new generation of brunels , stephensons and telfords .

documents.title: javid says bbc must continue to cut costs
text: sajid javid , the culture secretary , used his speech to warn the bbc that it must continue to cut costs .
we just want to ensure your money is spent carefully .
that 's why we froze the licence fee in 2010 .
and why i continue to challenge them to do more for less .
because receiving public money is a privilege , not a right .
javid also confirms that he wants to force mobile phone companies to improve their coverage , especially in rural areas .

in the conference hall the speeches have been a bit routine so far ( i 'll post summaries when i see the texts ) , but there is some excitement on the fringe at a meeting where benefits street 's white dee has been criticising government welfare policies and saying she might back ukip .
emily ashton ( @ elashton ) white dee hits out at jobs offered to benefit claimants : 'not everyone wants to work in an office or build a wall . '
emily ashton ( @ elashton ) white dee might run for parliament .
'but i would want to start at the bottom.i would n't want to go straight in and have david cameron 's job . '
tom newton dunn ( @ tnewtondunn ) benefits street 's white dee tells @ twitterid exchange she may abandon labour to vote ukip ( mixed publicity for both ) .
you can read all the guardian 's conservative conference coverage here .
as for the rest of the papers , here are some articles i found particularly interesting .
daniel hannan , the conservative mep , says in the daily mail that ukip and the conservatives should agree local pacts not to fight against each other in marginal seats .
david cameron and nigel farage have so far refused to discuss how to make such an outcome less likely .
with candidates on both sides now beginning their campaigns , a formal pact looks impossible .
the conservatives fret that it would lose them some centrist voters , while ukip worry about alienating former labour supporters who are inclining in their direction .
if it 's too late for a full-scale alliance , though , the case for local arrangements in key marginal seats remains .
it costs a party nothing to stand down in a constituency which it ca n't win .
from a conservative point of view , a ukip mp is surely preferable to a labour one .
from a ukip point of view , it must be better to get an in/out referendum than not .
we do n't do pacts , ' say some tories .
nonsense .
conservatives had pacts with the liberal unionists , the coupon ' liberals of 1918 and , for six general elections after the second world war , the national liberals .
we had such a deal as recently as the last election with the ulster unionist party .
david cameron tells the sun ( paywall ) in an interview that he is not ashamed of his family background .
cameron said : you ca n't change who you are , and i am not going to change who i am .
i ca n't change the school i went to , or the upbringing i had , or the parents i have and nor would i want to .
i am the first of my family not to be a stockbroker in about six generations .
i am sorry , what am i meant to do ?
rewrite history ?
i am proud of my dad .
he was passionate about bringing up a family and trying to do the best for us .
boris johnson says in his daily telegraph column that any tories thinking of defecting to ukip must be nuts .

let me try to reason with any would-be jumpers and auto-defenestrators in my party , the folk who want to launch themselves headlong into the silage , because i genuinely think that they ( if they indeed exist ) must be utterly nuts but consider , my dear fellow eurosceptic : there is only one prime minister in the current eu who is capable of collating that support and turning it into a new treaty , and only one man who is going to be able to give the people of this country the vote on the eu that we have been deprived of for the past 40 years , and that man is david cameron .
paul goodman in the daily telegraph says cameron needs to do more to repair relations with his backbenchers .
ronald reagan had a phrase for keeping the faithful happy : dance with the one that brung ya .
all too often , tory mps feel that mr cameron has left them lonely on the dance floor and that his attempts to sweet-talk them back lack sincerity .
mr reckless 's defection simply carried their distrust to an extreme .
downing street protests that this is unfair , and that no modern conservative leader has done more to keep his colleagues in touch .
but many mps are simply unconvinced .
there is a long history of bad blood , running from the candidates ' a-list project through last summer 's syrian debacle all the way to the scottish referendum .
i did n't know how much the prime minister was hated on the back-benches till i left the government , one former minister told me .
cabinet members out of the loop , a tiny leadership clique the complaints are familiar .
what is less certain is what mr cameron can now do about them .
he is unlikely to persuade his party this week that downing street will no longer be run like a branch of lastminute.com , in the words of a conservative back-bencher .

what he can do , perhaps , is show that last week 's chequers summit with tory mps on the constitution heralded a change that his election campaign will be based on real , structured , formal teamwork with his cabinet colleagues , ministers , mps and party members .
matthew holehouse in the daily telegraph says john hayes , a transport minister and cameron 's parliamentary adviser , told a fringe meeting that politicians should be paid more .
hayes said : i take the view that all this rubbish about politicians being over-paid and so on , we 've got to challenge it .
it does n't matter whether it is parish , or district , or county , or parliament .
the daily telegraph says cameron told a meeting of activists that the party would throw everything we can at beating ukip in the rochester byelection .
oliver wright in the independent offers five reasons why brooks newmark should not have resigned .
the conference proceedings have started , and matthew hancock , the skills minister , is speaking now .
i 'll summarise the key points when i 've seen the text .
ladbrokes say their odds have ukip has a virtual dead cert to win the clacton byelection .
they are also making ukip favourites to win in rochester and strood , although the early money is going on a tory victory .
here 's an excerpt from their news release .
douglas carswell is now considered a certainty by the bookies , with odds of just 1/50 for ukip to win their first seat in clacton .
mark reckless is also favourite in rochester & strood but only just ; the early money has been for the tories to hold on .
meanwhile , speculation is mounting about a possible third tory defecting to ukip .
ladbrokes quote evens that another mp makes the switch and mark pritchard is favourite to be the next to go .
ros altmann , the pensions expert , has written a helpful blog for the spectator about the pension tax cut announced by george osborne overnight .
here 's an excerpt .
there has been much concern expressed about the recent pension reforms encouraging people to spend their pension funds too soon , leaving them in poverty later on .
these tax changes will provide a significant incentive for people to keep their money in the pension fund , where it can earn tax free returns , until they really need it .
owen paterson , the former environment secretary , told the today programme earlier that the conservatives should be respectful towards ukip .
we have to be absolutely clear to those small c conservatives out there , who may be sitting back at the moment , some of them might be minded to go to protest parties like ukip .

we 've got to be respectful with them , and we 've got to make a very clear , intelligent , case that the only national organisation that can resolve the long-term problems of the united kingdom is the conservative party .
i 've taken the quote from politicshome .
sajid javid , the culture secretary , is in charge of media policy .
but when he was asked on radio 5 live whether or not he thought the sunday mirror sting against brooks newmark was justified , he dodged the question .

each case is different and i think you ca n't just give a yes or no answer it 's been reported - and i do n't know if it 's entirely correct but it may well be so i have to be careful - there may be some legal action involved in this and i think it would be inappropriate for me to make any comment on it .
in the comments kriegersclones says that mark pritchard 's complaint to the met policy about the sunday mirror sting is a non-starter .
kriegersclones 29 september 2014 9:11am pritchard 's complaint to scotland yard will fall flat .
unless the person involved is entrapped by being led into committing a criminal offence , then there 's nothing to complain about .
and if there had been a criminal act and a resulting charge , entrapment is not a defence under english law ( r v sang [ 1980 ] ac 402 ) .
entrapment is seen as an abuse of court process .

documents.title: george osborne 's morning interviews - summary
text: here are the key points from the various interviews george osborne has given this morning .
osborne signalled that the conservatives would be announcing further welfare cuts .
our welfare bill is too high as a country .
we face enormous economic challenges in the world and we ca n't as a country afford to have a very large working-age welfare bill .
there is speculation that the big announcement expected in his speech will be about further welfare cuts .
he said the state should not be paying for young people to spend their life on the dole .
we 've got to stop paying for a young generation to spend a life on the dole when we should be equipping them with apprenticeships and training to make the most of life .
this was a defence of the plan announced yesterday to fund more apprenticeships by cutting the welfare cap .
he said ed miliband 's claim that the link between living standards and the state of the national economy has broken was a dangerous myth .

i totally reject this fallacy , which is repeated by labour politicians , sometimes dare i say it aired on this programme , that the link between the national economy and people 's personal economies is fundamentally broken .
you tell that to th many tens of thousands of people who lost their jobs when the economy crashed six or seven years ago .

you tell that to people who as a result of the great recession are much poorer and whose opportunities in life have been curbed because of the failure of economic policy so i do n't accept that the link has been broken .
i think it is a dangerous myth .
it is put about by people who basically would trash the economy again and say do n't worry , because it is not going to affect you .
i 'm afraid people would bitterly live to regret that .
this was in some ways the most interesting thing osborne said all morning , although not the most newsworthy .
osborne is a politician with a serious interest in ideas , and here , for the first time , he was using a new argument to take a central plank , perhaps the central plank , of milibandism .
ed miliband thinks the economy needs to be restructured because the link between personal well-being and economic growth has broken .
in the past , when the economy grew , take-home pay in real terms went up too , but for the last 10 years or so it has n't .

osborne took this on ; but he did so , essentially , by twisting miliband 's argument , and implying that miliband was arguing that the state of the economy does n't matter ( which is not what miliband has been saying at all . )
he confirmed that conservative backbenchers will be free to campaign for britain to leave the eu in the proposed eu referendum .
he sidestepped a question about whether he could imagine circumstances in which it would be good for britain to leave the eu .
citing what david cameron said yesterday , osborne said if he did not think it was in britain 's interests to be in the eu , would not argue for it .
he claimed the scottish independence referendum had reversed the move towards independence .
for the first time in my lifetime , the march of the separatists in scotland has been reversed .
this is highly questionable , to say the least .
he said he would urge people considering voting ukip to remember that the general election essentially amounts to a choice between cameron and miliband .
you can either have ed miliband and no plan for the economy , or david cameron and a plan for the economy that is working .
and that is , in the end , the only two outcomes of the general election .

the more people focus on that choice , the more people visualise downing street and who is going to walk through the door after that general election , the more people realise that it is the conservative party who offer a brighter future for our country .
he said his proposed pension tax cut announced overnight was not just something for tory supporters .
this is not for core conservative supporters .
this is for everyone who works hard and saves hard for their retirement .

there are people with pension pots of â£ 20,000 , â£ 30,000 , â£ 40,000 who currently pay a 55 % tax if they try and pass on any unused part of that pension to their children and their grandchildren and others and i 'm getting rid of that tax altogether .
i 'm saying if you 've worked hard and saved hard , it 's your money and you should be able to decide what you want to do with it after you die .
it 's a big boost for savings , it 's a big boost for aspiration , it 's on the side of people doing the right thing for themselves and their families .

documents.title: tory mp asking police to investigate whether sunday mirror sting was illegal
text: the conservative mp mark pritchard says that , as well as reporting the sunday mirror to the press regulator ( see 8.07am ) , he is also going to ask the police if the law was broken .
mark pritchard ( @ mpritchardmp ) test for ipso and met police .
i will write to both today about sunday mirror story .
was the criminal law and ipso code of conduct broken ?

documents.title: george osborne 's today interview - twitter reaction
text: here 's some twitter comment from journalists , commentators and opponents on george osborne 's today interview .
from the spectator 's fraser nelson fraser nelson ( @ frasernelson ) `` the march of scottish separatists has been reversed , '' boasts osborne .
funny , i could have sworn they got 45 % of the vote .
from rory bremner rory bremner ( @ rorybremner ) 'the march of the separatists has been reversed ' says osborne , once again showing his tin ear for scottish politics .
from the independent 's andy mcsmith andy mcsmith ( @ andymcsmith ) osborne 's curious view of history that `` we '' joined the eu for economic reasons only .
he should have listened to edward heath who took us in .

from the sun 's tom newton dunn tom newton dunn ( @ tnewtondunn ) i 've heard @ twitterid osborne is holding back a jumbo rabbit for his # cpc14 speech today ; @ twitterid says its a big benefits cut .
from damian mcbride , gordon brown 's former spin doctor damian mcbride ( @ dpmcbride ) will @ twitterid4today hold osborne to the same standard as labour on the deficit ?
my blog : damian mcbride ( @ dpmcbride ) nope , @ twitterid4today lets osborne puff up a â£ 150m tax cut but does n't ask him how he 's paying for it .
a disgrace : from alex belardinelli , ed balls ' spin doctor alex belardinelli ( @ abelardinelli ) good point by @ twitterid - osborne borrowing more than planned .
â£ 190bn more in this parliament because of 3 years of lost growth after 2010 .
from labour mp chris bryant chris bryant ( @ chrisbryantmp ) osborne completely wrong .
when geoffrey howe introduced eec bill as attorney general he made absolutely clear the political nature of eec
we 've now got the nick robinson post-match analysis .
he says the eu referendum is a bit like the scottish referendum ; for some people , it is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to get out , more important than party .
robinson says he also expects osborne to announce a big cut in welfare in his speech .
osborne seemed to anticipate that in his final answer , robinson says .
i 'll post a summary of the highlights from osborne 's interviews soon .
q : in june 2010 you forecast borrowing would be â£ 58bn less than it is now .
osborne says many people expected borrowing to fall more quickly .
q : when will people see their take-home pay going up ?
osborne says people who did not have jobs are now in work .
he says he does not accept that the link between the national economy and people 's circusmtances is broken .
tell that to people who lost their jobs in the recession .
it is a dangerous myth put out by people who trashed the economy , he says .
q : will interest rates go up before the election ?
that 's a matter for the bank of england , says osborne .
the government is taking steps to help people , like the new homes announcement on saturday .
q : and some people are going to find the impact of further cuts very hard .
osborne says the welfare bill is too high .
as a country , we can not afford that .
and we have to stop paying for a younger generation to spend a life on the dole when they could be doing apprenticeships .
the government has set out plans on this .
it is a practical , future-orientated policy of the kind you will see at this conference , he says .
and that 's it .
q : why do n't you promise , if you do n't get the renegotiation you want , you will campaign for no vote ?
osborne says politicians should say what they want to achieve .
there is no point talking about the economic plan he does n't want ; he talks about the one he does want .
q : mps like mark reckless think that you assure fellow eu ministers the uk can never leave .
can you imagine circumstances in which you might argue for exit ?
osborne says , as david cameron said yesterday , he would only argue for what is in the national interest .
anyone who doubts whether the prime minister will deliver should look at scotland .
cameron promised referendum and there was one .
for the first time , the march of the separatists has been stopped .
q : are you happy with tory candidates saying they will vote to leave ?
osborne says the party 's position will be clear .
ultimately backbenchers will have a free vote .
q : is it okay for candidates to promise to vote no ?
osborne says the policy they will be backing will be to have a referendum .

documents.title: george osborne 's today inteview
text: james naughtie is interviewing george osborne .
q : do you accept that , going into the election , a substantial section of the party questions whether the uk should stay in the eu ?
osborne says a substantial section of the country , not just the party , think this .
the only way it can be resolved is by a referendum .
q : sir martin sorrell said this morning an eu referendum would be even more disruptive than a scottish one .
osborne says business wants the eu to be reformed .
it is worried about europe pricing itself out of business .
q : the eef , an employers ' organisation , said 85 % of its members want to stay in the eu .
how much support do you find for leaving ?
osborne says small businesses have very strong views .
they are on the frontline of eu regulation .
the uk joined because of the economic future it offered .
that is not working at the moment .
so it has to be changed .
tom edgington ( @ edgingtont ) coming up at 8.10am : the chancellor @ twitterid osborne on @ twitterid4today # cpc14 # conservativeconference

documents.title: tory mp complains to press regulator over sunday mirror sting
text: mark pritchard , one of the mps contacted by a sunday mirror reporter posing as a woman interested in sex , is to make a formal complaint to the uk newspaper regulator ipso , the guardian reports .
pritchard revealed his move on twitter .
mark pritchard ( @ mpritchardmp ) test case for ipso will be making formal complaint over attempted entrapment by mirror .
appears even single mps ca n't have a `` private life '' the labour mp chris bryant seems to support the move .
chris bryant ( @ chrisbryantmp ) i ca n't see how mirror 's fishing expedition to trap tory mps was in public interest .
rather pathetic .
prurience & judgmentalism do n't mix
it is george osborne 's day at the conservative conference in birmingham .

we 're expecting a significant announcement in his speech , at the end of the morning session of the economy , and , along with david cameron 's speech on wednesday , this is supposed to be one of the two main events of the conference .
one announcement in the speech has already been briefed overnight - a cut in the tax paid when pension pots are passed on to a beneficiary when someone dies .
as faisal islam points out , for a relatively small tax cut , it is generating very positive headlines .
faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) extraordinary set of positive headlines from a tiny tax cut of â£ 150m equivalent of 0.03p off basic rate .
efficient .
osborne has been giving interviews this morning and he will be on the today programme shortly .
i 'll be covering that in detail .
here 's the agenda for the day .
8.10am : george osborne , the chancellor , is interviewed on the today programme .
10.35am : matthew hancock , the skills minister speaks .
10.45am : sajid javid , the culture secretary , speaks .
11.20am : liz truss , the environment secretary , speaks .
11.30am : patrick mcloughlin , the transport secretary , speaks .
11.50am : osborne speaks .
2.40pm : francis maude , the cabinet office minister , speaks .
3pm : eric pickles , the culture secretary , speaks .
3.40pm : iain duncan smith , the work and pensions secretary , speaks .
i 'll be covering all the conference news , as well as bringing reaction and highlighting the best comment and analysis on the web .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .

bulletin.text: Tory MP asks Met police to investigate Sunday Mirror sting.
Osborne announces plan to save Â£ 3bn by freezing working-age benefits.
Redwood says firms will pay price if they campaign for EU.
